To Las Vegas or Monaco
And win a fortune in a game
My life will never be the same

[Chorus]
Money, money, money
Must be funny
In the rich man's world
Money, money, money
Always sunny
In the rich man's world
A-ha, ah
All the things I could do
If I had a little money
It's a rich man's world
You might also like[Chorus]
Money, money, money
Must be funny
In the rich man's world
Money, money, money
Always sunny
In the rich man's world
A-ha, ah
All the things I could do
If I had a little money
It's a rich man's world

[Outro]
It's a rich man's world15Embed
annotation:
[('There never seems to be a single penny left for me', [['This line is possibly autobiographical and an allegorical reference to what was happening in the group’s own country.

When Sweden was facing a 1976 general election, there was a debate around taxation and scrutinisation of the Social Democratic Party and its leader Olof Palme. The actions of the Swedish government, regarding taxation, has affected celebrities ranging from author Astrid Lindgren to director Ingmar Bergman.

Lindgren famously proclaimed that her taxation rate was 102% percent in her story “Pomperipossa in Monismania”, published in March 1976; interestingly, in the story, when Pomperipossa calculates what will be left to her, the calculation gave her 2,000 kronor, which infuriated her to the point that she questioned how she would get her food, while the rest of the kronor went to the welfare state, as Expressen elaborates in 2007. “A single penny” is not a single penny in a literal sense, but a metaphor of saying that there is remaining money for a person, but not enough to sustain themselves.

Bergman was reportedly charged for evading taxes through a foreign company based in Switzerland that distributed films outside Sweden. While he did indeed form a distribution company, he denied that he had any intentions to bypass Sweden’s tax system, according to the New York Times. Altogether, the taxation conflicts and grievances soon became a catalyst for ousting the Social Democratic Party from being the majority party in the Riksdag in the 1976 election.

Although this single and its accompanying album Arrival was released after the election and Lindgren’s story, The Guardian, Petter Karlsson and Jan Gradvall, in their 2014 book “ABBA: The Official Photo Book” revealed that ABBA and Polar Music avoided heavy taxation by wearing glam-inspired clothes that were to be used for only performances and not for the streets. In short, ABBA, to a certain extent, were not very fond of taxation.']]), ('So I must leave, I’ll have to go
 To Las Vegas or Monaco
 And win a fortune in a game
 My life will never be the same', [['If her rich husband is nowhere in sight, she muses that the easiest way to get the money would be through gambling. The fact that she must resort to random chance serves to further emphasize how unlikely it is that she would become rich.

Las Vegas and Monaco are the two most recognizable gambling destinations. Las Vegas is home to world famous casinos, and is almost synonymous with gambling, while Monaco is a small European country, home to the Monte Carlo Casino.']]), ('If I got me a wealthy man
 I wouldn’t have to work at all
 I’d fool around and have a ball', [['If she had a wealthy husband, she’d never have to work another day in her life. Gold Digger anyone?

This plays on the double meaning of “a ball.” In this life she would “have a ball,” or have fun not working, but she might also decide to host a formal party- the sort of masquerade ball so often associated with fairy tales.']])]

annotation:
[('Voulez-vous?', [['This could very well be a reference to the cabaret song Lady Marmalade, by Patti Labelle, which topped the charts in 1974 and 1975, a few years before this hit was released:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zgLSeBPfVNM

It popularized the French expression:

Voulez-vous coucher avec moi ce soir ?"

Which literaly means: “Do you wanna sleep with me tonight?”']]), ('La question c’est «Voulez-vous?»
 Voulez-vous?', [['This line translates to “The question is ‘do you want to’” in English. Again, a furthering of the song’s theme of push and pull between two people who meet at a bar and are uncertain of the next step. Except in gratituous French.']])]

A big thing or a small (Big or small)
The winner takes it all (Takes it all)

[Verse 4]
I don't wanna talk
If it makes you feel sad
And I understand, you've come to shake my hand
I apologise
If it makes you feel bad
Seeing me so tense, no self-confidence

[Bridge]
But you see, the winner takes it all
The winner takes it all

[Outro]
(So the winner)
(Takes it all)
(And the loser)
(Has to fall)
(Throw a dice)
(Cold as ice)
(Way down here)
(Someone dear)
(Takes it all)
(Has to fall)
(It seems plain)
(Why complain)18Embed
annotation:
[('The gods may throw a dice
 Their minds as cold as ice
 And someone way down here
 Loses someone dear', [['Think this lyrics may be related to teological determinism; the consideration of the idea that divine higher beings have the power to dictate the events in earth, on this case it being related to a breakup.']]), ('Spectators of the show (Of the show)
 Always staying low (Staying low)', [['These two lines depict a messy public fight, not unlike their divorce that received heavy media coverage. The journalists watching the fight stay out of sight, snapping photographs to be printed the next day. It’s also likely that Ulvaeus and Fältskog are taking a dig at journalists that write false stories.

In a 1981 interview with The Daily Mirror,Agnetha said:

Swedish newspapers always write untruths about me, so I know that no one is going to believe me, but I really don’t have a steady boyfriend

By calling them spectators, they opine that journalists are complete outsiders and don’t really matter too much to them.']]), ('The game is on again (On again)
 A lover or a friend (Or a friend)
 A big thing or a small (Big or small)
 The winner takes it all (Takes it all)', [['Ulvaeus and Fältskog are locked in a heated battle regarding their divorce and the custody of their children.

Björn Ulvaeus has argued that the song isn’t about his and Fältskog’s divorce but instead a piece of fiction:

There was not one winner in the case of us, so it’s pure fiction. But going through a divorce is difficult as anyone would know who has done it and er, it makes you think about it’s like a failure, yeah, it’s difficult and er, maybe that was one way of getting it out of my system.

But in a 2013 interview with The Daily Mail, Agnetha Fältskog described the song very differently.

Björn wrote it about us after the breakdown of our marriage. The fact he wrote it exactly when we divorced is touching really. I didn’t mind. It was fantastic to do that song because I could put in such feeling.']]), ('The judges will decide (They decide)
 The likes of me abide (We abide)', [['Frontman for ABBA at the time Björn Ulvaeus and his wife and fellow recording artist Agnetha Fältskog had two children when they divorced.

As this song was written by Ulvaeus, these lyrics are likely him lamenting that Fältskog got custody of their children and not him.']])]

annotation: [('Super Trouper beams are gonna blind me', [['Super Trouper lights are spotlights that are designed to shine bright on stages. In 1956, when such lights were introduced to the public, they were considered to be the brightest lights in the world, hence why the singers seem to be “blinded” by the lights.\n\nAfter the release of the song, the Super Troupers became one of the best known stage lights in the stage industry.']])]

annotation:
[('[Verse 2]', [['Similar to “I Do, I Do, I Do, I Do, I Do” from their previous album, “Dancing Queen” originally had more lyrics during the demoing process. The following lines can be heard in a recording session and would have ultimately made the second verse equal in length to the first:

Baby, baby, you’re out of sight
Hey, you’re looking alright tonight
When you come to the party, listen to the guys
They’ve got the look in their eyes

While these lines don’t appear in the English recording, the Spanish rerecording includes this lengthening of the verse, though the words are not a translation of the above.']]), ('Night is young and the music’s high', [['Many fans misinterpret this lyric, thinking it’s about music making you high—but in ABBA’s native Sweden, “high” means “loud.”']])]

annotation:
[('We can go dancing, we can go walking
 As long as we’re together (As long as we’re together)
 Listen to some music, maybe just talking
 Get to know you better (Get to know you better)', [['They’re picturing all the romantic things they could do together if they were a couple. However, they may have romanticized the idea of this person a bit much. Sometimes when you have an idea of someone, they don’t live up to what you painted it to be in your mind.']]), ('If you need me, let me know, gonna be around', [['They will always be there for this person. It seems like a bit of a one way street – with a lot of care being given and none being reciprocated but the singer doesn’t mind.

The “pretty birds” may refer to all the other pretty girls/guys the person has in their life. When they’ve all left, he/she will still be there waiting. Birds also migrate to different countries during winter, and in this context they could be referring to the cold and hard times of life. Even in the cold and difficult times, they’ll still be there to support.']])]

annotation:
[('The gods may throw a dice
 Their minds as cold as ice
 And someone way down here
 Loses someone dear', [['Think this lyrics may be related to teological determinism; the consideration of the idea that divine higher beings have the power to dictate the events in earth, on this case it being related to a breakup.']]), ('Spectators of the show (Of the show)
 Always staying low (Staying low)', [['These two lines depict a messy public fight, not unlike their divorce that received heavy media coverage. The journalists watching the fight stay out of sight, snapping photographs to be printed the next day. It’s also likely that Ulvaeus and Fältskog are taking a dig at journalists that write false stories.

In a 1981 interview with The Daily Mirror,Agnetha said:

Swedish newspapers always write untruths about me, so I know that no one is going to believe me, but I really don’t have a steady boyfriend

By calling them spectators, they opine that journalists are complete outsiders and don’t really matter too much to them.']]), ('The game is on again (On again)
 A lover or a friend (Or a friend)
 A big thing or a small (Big or small)
 The winner takes it all (Takes it all)', [['Ulvaeus and Fältskog are locked in a heated battle regarding their divorce and the custody of their children.

Björn Ulvaeus has argued that the song isn’t about his and Fältskog’s divorce but instead a piece of fiction:

There was not one winner in the case of us, so it’s pure fiction. But going through a divorce is difficult as anyone would know who has done it and er, it makes you think about it’s like a failure, yeah, it’s difficult and er, maybe that was one way of getting it out of my system.

But in a 2013 interview with The Daily Mail, Agnetha Fältskog described the song very differently.

Björn wrote it about us after the breakdown of our marriage. The fact he wrote it exactly when we divorced is touching really. I didn’t mind. It was fantastic to do that song because I could put in such feeling.']]), ('The judges will decide (They decide)
 The likes of me abide (We abide)', [['Frontman for ABBA at the time Björn Ulvaeus and his wife and fellow recording artist Agnetha Fältskog had two children when they divorced.

As this song was written by Ulvaeus, these lyrics are likely him lamenting that Fältskog got custody of their children and not him.']])]

title: Money, Money, Money

annotation:
[('There never seems to be a single penny left for me', [['This line is possibly autobiographical and an allegorical reference to what was happening in the group’s own country.

When Sweden was facing a 1976 general election, there was a debate around taxation and scrutinisation of the Social Democratic Party and its leader Olof Palme. The actions of the Swedish government, regarding taxation, has affected celebrities ranging from author Astrid Lindgren to director Ingmar Bergman.

Lindgren famously proclaimed that her taxation rate was 102% percent in her story “Pomperipossa in Monismania”, published in March 1976; interestingly, in the story, when Pomperipossa calculates what will be left to her, the calculation gave her 2,000 kronor, which infuriated her to the point that she questioned how she would get her food, while the rest of the kronor went to the welfare state, as Expressen elaborates in 2007. “A single penny” is not a single penny in a literal sense, but a metaphor of saying that there is remaining money for a person, but not enough to sustain themselves.

Bergman was reportedly charged for evading taxes through a foreign company based in Switzerland that distributed films outside Sweden. While he did indeed form a distribution company, he denied that he had any intentions to bypass Sweden’s tax system, according to the New York Times. Altogether, the taxation conflicts and grievances soon became a catalyst for ousting the Social Democratic Party from being the majority party in the Riksdag in the 1976 election.

Although this single and its accompanying album Arrival was released after the election and Lindgren’s story, The Guardian, Petter Karlsson and Jan Gradvall, in their 2014 book “ABBA: The Official Photo Book” revealed that ABBA and Polar Music avoided heavy taxation by wearing glam-inspired clothes that were to be used for only performances and not for the streets. In short, ABBA, to a certain extent, were not very fond of taxation.']]), ('So I must leave, I’ll have to go
 To Las Vegas or Monaco
 And win a fortune in a game
 My life will never be the same', [['If her rich husband is nowhere in sight, she muses that the easiest way to get the money would be through gambling. The fact that she must resort to random chance serves to further emphasize how unlikely it is that she would become rich.

Las Vegas and Monaco are the two most recognizable gambling destinations. Las Vegas is home to world famous casinos, and is almost synonymous with gambling, while Monaco is a small European country, home to the Monte Carlo Casino.']]), ('If I got me a wealthy man
 I wouldn’t have to work at all
 I’d fool around and have a ball', [['If she had a wealthy husband, she’d never have to work another day in her life. Gold Digger anyone?

This plays on the double meaning of “a ball.” In this life she would “have a ball,” or have fun not working, but she might also decide to host a formal party- the sort of masquerade ball so often associated with fairy tales.']])]

annotation:
[('[Intro]', [['A whimsical orchestral musical lead through – to a fictitious tale of a historical battle survivors.

This song is Pop at his best, and it was a fresh change from the rule of disco in the latter part of the 70’s.']]), ('Now we’re old and grey, Fernando', [['The song writer, Bjotn Ulvaeus, had said in an interview –

That lyric [of the original song in Swedish] is so banal and I didn’t like it. It was a love lyric, someone who loved Fernando, but I inherited the word ‘Fernando’ and I thought long and hard, what does Fernando tell me? I was in my summerhouse one starry evening and the words came, ‘There was something in the air that night’ and I thought of two old comrades from some guerrilla war in Mexico who would be sitting in the porch and reminiscing about what happened to them back then and this is what it is all about. Total fiction.

From here']]), ('There was something in the air that night
 The stars were bright, Fernando', [['These corny lines were inviting a parody – they were used in an episode of That 70’s Show TV sitcom, incorporated into the spoken (an sung) narrative.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w0r3oYB2rV8']]), ('Yes, if I had to do the same again
 I would, my friend, Fernando', [['Despite being Abba’s most successful song, it was played only for a few seconds in the musical Mamma Mia which was built around the group’s songs – both in the stage production and in the film, hummed by Donna for a few seconds, while repairing a door in the taverna.



Fortunately, un “Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again”, however, the song does appear, as Ruby Sheridan meets her long-ago friend and lover, Fernando Cienfuegos.']]), ('[Verse 3]', [['Again – melodious, far from rock, though the Bass chords lines have been praised by many.']]), ('I could hear the distant drums and sounds of bugle calls were coming from afar', [['Another clue to their role in the war – sounds “were coming from afar” – and why they survived to tell the (fictitious) story…



Drums and bugle players indeed accompanied troops in the 19th century.']]), ('I remember, long ago, another starry night like this
 In the firelight, Fernando', [['Not to be too picky – these are nice rhymes, but it is doubtful they saw too many stars “in the firelight”, even if it was a “starry night”.

Or perhaps it was a subconscious referral for much more likely situation of “seeing stars” in a fight –']]), ('Do you still recall the fateful night we crossed the Rio Grande?', [['The Rio Grande – “The Grand River” that flows from the Rockies through New Mexico into Mexico and to the gulf of Mexico, serving since 1848 as the border between Mexico and the United States.



It serves as the scene for the fictitious story in the song of two soldiers, probably Mexicans, participating in the Mexican American War of 1846-8, revolving around the Rio Grands.

Another possibility is that it was a (fictitious again) song by veterans of the Mexican Revolution of 1910.']]), ('There was something in the air that night
 The stars were bright, Fernando', [['The song was originally recorded solo by Abba singer Anni-Frid Lyngstad as a love song with same name. The lyricist (the male members of Abba) decided that the Swedish lyrics were too corny, so they rewrote the lyrics in  English to sound less inane..

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_QKLMCssXzs

The song’s original name was Tango, then Hernandez and finally some combination of the two…

The chorus translation –

“Long live love, our best friend, Fernando.
Raise your glass and propose a toast to it, to love, Fernando.
Play the melody and sing a song of happiness.
Long live love, Fernando.

These two lines are probably the only ones that survived from the original version.']])]

annotation:
[('Voulez-vous?', [['This could very well be a reference to the cabaret song Lady Marmalade, by Patti Labelle, which topped the charts in 1974 and 1975, a few years before this hit was released:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zgLSeBPfVNM

It popularized the French expression:

Voulez-vous coucher avec moi ce soir ?"

Which literaly means: “Do you wanna sleep with me tonight?”']]), ('La question c’est «Voulez-vous?»
 Voulez-vous?', [['This line translates to “The question is ‘do you want to’” in English. Again, a furthering of the song’s theme of push and pull between two people who meet at a bar and are uncertain of the next step. Except in gratituous French.']])]

title: Waterloo

[Pre-Chorus]

[Chorus]

[Outro]

Finally facing my Waterloo
Woo, Waterloo, knowing my fate is to be with youYou might also like16Embed
annotation:
[('And how could I ever refuse?
 I feel like I win when I lose', [['Unlike Napoleon Bonaparte, who certainly did not feel as though he won after losing the Battle of Waterloo (he was exiled to St. Helena, where he died in 1821), this singer doesn’t mind “losing” because the result is that she is now with her lover.']]), ('My, my - I tried to hold you back, but you were stronger
 Oh, yeah - and now it seems my only chance is giving up the fight', [["At the Battle of Waterloo, the French (led by Napoleon) only had an army of 72,000 while the Anglo-led Allied European coalition had nearly 120,000 soldiers.

That said, despite the Allies' numerical advantage, Napoleon nearly won at Waterloo. The Duke of Wellington called the battle “the nearest run thing you ever saw in your life.”

Napoleon was also accustomed to victory in spite of numerical disadvantage – his most auspicious victory was the Battle of Austerlitz, where he decisively and simultaneously defeated   the Holy Roman Empire and Russia, despite his 67,000 soldiers being outnumbered by their 85,400."]]), ('My, my - at Waterloo, Napoleon did surrender
 Oh, yeah - and I have met my destiny in quite a similar way', [['Napoleon Bonaparte was decisively defeated by an Anglo-led European coalition at the Battle of Waterloo in 1815. This song uses the battle as a metaphor for a woman who gives in and falls in love with a man – he’s her “Waterloo.”

This line is actually historically inaccurate, however. Waterloo did mark Napoleon’s final defeat, but he did not surrender at the battle itself on June 18. He instead retreated to France, abdicating on June 24, and surrendering on July 15.']])]

title: The Day Before You Came
lyrics:
The Day Before You Came Lyrics[Verse 1: Agnetha]
I must have left my house at eight because I always do
My train, I'm certain, left the station just when it was due
I must have read the morning paper going into town
And having gotten through the editorial no doubt I must have frowned
I must have made my desk around a quarter after nine
With letters to be read and heaps of papers waiting to be signed
I must have gone to lunch
At half past twelve or so, the usual place, the usual bunch
And still on top of this I'm pretty sure it must have rained
The day before you came
[Verse 2: Agnetha]
I must have lit my seventh cigarette at half past two
And at the time I never even noticed I was blue
I must have kept on dragging through the business of the day
Without really knowing anything I hid a part of me away
At five I must have left, there's no exception to the rule
A matter of routine, I've done it ever since I finished school
The train back home again
Undoubtedly I must have read the evening paper then
Oh yes, I'm sure my life was well within its usual frame
The day before you came

[Vocalisations: Frida]

[Verse 3: Agnetha]
I must have opened my front door at eight o'clock or so
And stopped along the way to buy some Chinese food to go
I'm sure I had my dinner watching something on TV
There's not, I think, a single episode of "Dallas" that I didn't see
I must have gone to bed around a quarter after ten
I need a lot of sleep and so I like to be in bed by then
I must have read a while
The latest one by Marilyn French, or something in that style
It's funny, but I had no sense of living without aim
The day before you came
You might also like[Outro: Agnetha]
And turning out the light
I must have yawned and cuddled up for yet another night
And rattling on the roof I must have heard the sound of rain
The day before you came

[Vocalisations: Frida]3Embed

annotation:
[('And your name is Harry', [['The meaning of this lyric is pretty confusing.  Did the person the narrator is speaking to change his name or something or is Harry just short for Harold, his actual name?

Harry Bright would later be the name of a character in the Broadway musical “Mamma Mia!”, in which the character Sophie sings this song to Harry.']]), ('Flower-power', [['The slogan ‘flower-power’ came from the late 1960s- early 1970s. Flowers were used as a symbol non-violence ideology, and commonly associated with the to the hippie movement.



John Lennon and Yoko Ono scattered masses of flowers around their hotel room during their famous Bed-In protest.']])]

annotation: [('Gonna show him I care, gonna teach him a lesson alright', [['Obviously a play on words. The world’s upside down: the student is the one teaching him a lesson.\n\nThis can also be a double-entendre. The “lesson” can either be a life lesson (echoing the fact the teacher was taken by surprise) or it can refer to some kinky sexual games.']])]

annotation: [('Pity, Cassandra, that no one believed you', [['Cassandra, in Greek mythology, was beloved of Apollo, and because he loved her he gave her the gift of prophecy. However, she did not return his love. As he could not take back the gift, he angrily cursed her that no one would believe her prophecies. Cassandra repeatedly warned her fellow Trojans about the Greek warriors hiding inside the Trojan Horse, but no one believed her.']])]

title: When All Is Said And Done

annotation:
[('But in time you will understand
 That the dreams we dreamed were made of sand', [['Things turning to or being made of sand are a recurring theme in Bjorn’s lyrics. A few years before, he wrote the lyrics for “Mitt Sommarland,” a song on one of Agnetha’s solo albums.

“Min drom blev till sand.” My dream turned to sand.

Years later, the imagery pops up again on Kristina Fran Duvemala on the track “Guldet Blev Till Sand.”

“Guldet blev till sand.” Gold turned to sand.

The basis for this metaphor is that sand is an unstable building material, and anything made out of sand will not last very long.']])]

annotation:
[('And how could I ever refuse?
 I feel like I win when I lose', [['Unlike Napoleon Bonaparte, who certainly did not feel as though he won after losing the Battle of Waterloo (he was exiled to St. Helena, where he died in 1821), this singer doesn’t mind “losing” because the result is that she is now with her lover.']]), ('My, my - I tried to hold you back, but you were stronger
 Oh, yeah - and now it seems my only chance is giving up the fight', [["At the Battle of Waterloo, the French (led by Napoleon) only had an army of 72,000 while the Anglo-led Allied European coalition had nearly 120,000 soldiers.

That said, despite the Allies' numerical advantage, Napoleon nearly won at Waterloo. The Duke of Wellington called the battle “the nearest run thing you ever saw in your life.”

Napoleon was also accustomed to victory in spite of numerical disadvantage – his most auspicious victory was the Battle of Austerlitz, where he decisively and simultaneously defeated   the Holy Roman Empire and Russia, despite his 67,000 soldiers being outnumbered by their 85,400."]]), ('My, my - at Waterloo, Napoleon did surrender
 Oh, yeah - and I have met my destiny in quite a similar way', [['Napoleon Bonaparte was decisively defeated by an Anglo-led European coalition at the Battle of Waterloo in 1815. This song uses the battle as a metaphor for a woman who gives in and falls in love with a man – he’s her “Waterloo.”

This line is actually historically inaccurate, however. Waterloo did mark Napoleon’s final defeat, but he did not surrender at the battle itself on June 18. He instead retreated to France, abdicating on June 24, and surrendering on July 15.']])]

annotation:
[('[Verse 2]', [['Similar to “I Do, I Do, I Do, I Do, I Do” from their previous album, “Dancing Queen” originally had more lyrics during the demoing process. The following lines can be heard in a recording session and would have ultimately made the second verse equal in length to the first:

Baby, baby, you’re out of sight
Hey, you’re looking alright tonight
When you come to the party, listen to the guys
They’ve got the look in their eyes

While these lines don’t appear in the English recording, the Spanish rerecording includes this lengthening of the verse, though the words are not a translation of the above.']]), ('Night is young and the music’s high', [['Many fans misinterpret this lyric, thinking it’s about music making you high—but in ABBA’s native Sweden, “high” means “loud.”']])]

title: Money, Money, Money
lyrics:

annotation:
[('There never seems to be a single penny left for me', [['This line is possibly autobiographical and an allegorical reference to what was happening in the group’s own country.

When Sweden was facing a 1976 general election, there was a debate around taxation and scrutinisation of the Social Democratic Party and its leader Olof Palme. The actions of the Swedish government, regarding taxation, has affected celebrities ranging from author Astrid Lindgren to director Ingmar Bergman.

Lindgren famously proclaimed that her taxation rate was 102% percent in her story “Pomperipossa in Monismania”, published in March 1976; interestingly, in the story, when Pomperipossa calculates what will be left to her, the calculation gave her 2,000 kronor, which infuriated her to the point that she questioned how she would get her food, while the rest of the kronor went to the welfare state, as Expressen elaborates in 2007. “A single penny” is not a single penny in a literal sense, but a metaphor of saying that there is remaining money for a person, but not enough to sustain themselves.

Bergman was reportedly charged for evading taxes through a foreign company based in Switzerland that distributed films outside Sweden. While he did indeed form a distribution company, he denied that he had any intentions to bypass Sweden’s tax system, according to the New York Times. Altogether, the taxation conflicts and grievances soon became a catalyst for ousting the Social Democratic Party from being the majority party in the Riksdag in the 1976 election.

Although this single and its accompanying album Arrival was released after the election and Lindgren’s story, The Guardian, Petter Karlsson and Jan Gradvall, in their 2014 book “ABBA: The Official Photo Book” revealed that ABBA and Polar Music avoided heavy taxation by wearing glam-inspired clothes that were to be used for only performances and not for the streets. In short, ABBA, to a certain extent, were not very fond of taxation.']]), ('So I must leave, I’ll have to go
 To Las Vegas or Monaco
 And win a fortune in a game
 My life will never be the same', [['If her rich husband is nowhere in sight, she muses that the easiest way to get the money would be through gambling. The fact that she must resort to random chance serves to further emphasize how unlikely it is that she would become rich.

Las Vegas and Monaco are the two most recognizable gambling destinations. Las Vegas is home to world famous casinos, and is almost synonymous with gambling, while Monaco is a small European country, home to the Monte Carlo Casino.']]), ('If I got me a wealthy man
 I wouldn’t have to work at all
 I’d fool around and have a ball', [['If she had a wealthy husband, she’d never have to work another day in her life. Gold Digger anyone?

This plays on the double meaning of “a ball.” In this life she would “have a ball,” or have fun not working, but she might also decide to host a formal party- the sort of masquerade ball so often associated with fairy tales.']])]

annotation:
[('We can go dancing, we can go walking
 As long as we’re together (As long as we’re together)
 Listen to some music, maybe just talking
 Get to know you better (Get to know you better)', [['They’re picturing all the romantic things they could do together if they were a couple. However, they may have romanticized the idea of this person a bit much. Sometimes when you have an idea of someone, they don’t live up to what you painted it to be in your mind.']]), ('If you need me, let me know, gonna be around', [['They will always be there for this person. It seems like a bit of a one way street – with a lot of care being given and none being reciprocated but the singer doesn’t mind.

The “pretty birds” may refer to all the other pretty girls/guys the person has in their life. When they’ve all left, he/she will still be there waiting. Birds also migrate to different countries during winter, and in this context they could be referring to the cold and hard times of life. Even in the cold and difficult times, they’ll still be there to support.']])]

annotation:
[('Voulez-vous?', [['This could very well be a reference to the cabaret song Lady Marmalade, by Patti Labelle, which topped the charts in 1974 and 1975, a few years before this hit was released:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zgLSeBPfVNM

It popularized the French expression:

Voulez-vous coucher avec moi ce soir ?"

Which literaly means: “Do you wanna sleep with me tonight?”']]), ('La question c’est «Voulez-vous?»
 Voulez-vous?', [['This line translates to “The question is ‘do you want to’” in English. Again, a furthering of the song’s theme of push and pull between two people who meet at a bar and are uncertain of the next step. Except in gratituous French.']])]

title: The Winner Takes It All
lyrics:

The winner takes it all (Takes it all)

[Verse 4]

[Bridge]

The winner takes it all

[Outro]
(So the winner)
(Takes it all)
(And the loser)
(Has to fall)
(Throw a dice)
(Cold as ice)
(Way down here)
(Someone dear)
(Takes it all)
(Has to fall)
(It seems plain)
(Why complain)18Embed
annotation:
[('The gods may throw a dice
 Their minds as cold as ice
 And someone way down here
 Loses someone dear', [['Think this lyrics may be related to teological determinism; the consideration of the idea that divine higher beings have the power to dictate the events in earth, on this case it being related to a breakup.']]), ('Spectators of the show (Of the show)
 Always staying low (Staying low)', [['These two lines depict a messy public fight, not unlike their divorce that received heavy media coverage. The journalists watching the fight stay out of sight, snapping photographs to be printed the next day. It’s also likely that Ulvaeus and Fältskog are taking a dig at journalists that write false stories.

In a 1981 interview with The Daily Mirror,Agnetha said:

Swedish newspapers always write untruths about me, so I know that no one is going to believe me, but I really don’t have a steady boyfriend

By calling them spectators, they opine that journalists are complete outsiders and don’t really matter too much to them.']]), ('The game is on again (On again)
 A lover or a friend (Or a friend)
 A big thing or a small (Big or small)
 The winner takes it all (Takes it all)', [['Ulvaeus and Fältskog are locked in a heated battle regarding their divorce and the custody of their children.

Björn Ulvaeus has argued that the song isn’t about his and Fältskog’s divorce but instead a piece of fiction:

There was not one winner in the case of us, so it’s pure fiction. But going through a divorce is difficult as anyone would know who has done it and er, it makes you think about it’s like a failure, yeah, it’s difficult and er, maybe that was one way of getting it out of my system.

But in a 2013 interview with The Daily Mail, Agnetha Fältskog described the song very differently.

Björn wrote it about us after the breakdown of our marriage. The fact he wrote it exactly when we divorced is touching really. I didn’t mind. It was fantastic to do that song because I could put in such feeling.']]), ('The judges will decide (They decide)
 The likes of me abide (We abide)', [['Frontman for ABBA at the time Björn Ulvaeus and his wife and fellow recording artist Agnetha Fältskog had two children when they divorced.

As this song was written by Ulvaeus, these lyrics are likely him lamenting that Fältskog got custody of their children and not him.']])]

annotation: [('Super Trouper beams are gonna blind me', [['Super Trouper lights are spotlights that are designed to shine bright on stages. In 1956, when such lights were introduced to the public, they were considered to be the brightest lights in the world, hence why the singers seem to be “blinded” by the lights.\n\nAfter the release of the song, the Super Troupers became one of the best known stage lights in the stage industry.']])]

title: Should I Laugh Or Cry
lyrics:
Should I Laugh or Cry Lyrics[Intro]
"Noll... ett, två, tre"

[Verse 1]
He stands towering over me beside my bed
Losing his head
Tells me I must take him seriously
Droning on, the usual way, he's such a clever guy
Then I wonder, should I laugh or cry?

[Verse 2]
He's dressed in the striped pyjamas that I bought
Trousers too short
Gives me of his small philosophy
Carries on the way he does, and me I get so tired
And I wonder, should I laugh or cry?
[Chorus]
High and mighty his banner flies
A fool's pride in his eyes
Standing there on his toes to grow in size (All I see is...)
All I see is a big balloon
Halfway up to the moon
He's wrapped up in the warm and safe cocoon
Of an eternal lie
So should I laugh or cry?

[Verse 3]
Strange how dangerously indifferent I have grown
Cold as a stone
No more pain where there was pain before
Far away he rambles on, I feel my throat go dry
And I wonder, should I laugh or cry?

[Chorus]
High and mighty his banner flies
A fool's pride in his eyes
Standing there on his toes to grow in size (All I see is...)
All I see is a big balloon
Halfway up to the moon
He's wrapped up in the warm and safe cocoon
Of an eternal lie
So should I laugh or cry?You might also like1Embed

title: Head Over Heels
lyrics:
Head Over Heels Lyrics[Verse 1]
I have a very good friend
The kind of girl who likes to follow a trend
She has a personal style
Some people like it, others tend to go wild
You hear her voice everywhere
Taking the chair
She's a leading lady
And with no trace of hesitation, she keeps going

[Chorus]
Head over heels, breaking her way
Pushing through unknown jungles every day
She's a girl with a taste for the world
(The world is like a playing-ground where she goes rushing)
Head over heels, setting the pace
Running the gauntlet in a whirl of lace
She's extreme, if you know what I mean
[Verse 2]
Her man is one I admire
He's so courageous but he's constantly tired
Each time when he speaks his mind
She pats his head and says, "Oh, that's all very fine
Exert that will of your own
When you're alone
Now we'd better hurry"
And with no trace of hesitation, she keeps going

[Chorus]
Head over heels, breaking her way
Pushing through unknown jungles every day
She's a girl with a taste for the world
(The world is like a playing-ground where she goes rushing)
Head over heels, setting the pace
Running the gauntlet in a whirl of lace
She's extreme, if you know what I mean

[Interlude]

[Verse 3]
You hear her voice everywhere
Taking the chair
She's a leading lady
And with no trace of hesitation, she keeps going
You might also like[Chorus]
Head over heels, breaking her way
Pushing through unknown jungles every day
She's a girl with a taste for the world
(The world is like a playing-ground where she goes rushing)
Head over heels, setting the pace

[Outro]

annotation:
[('Head over heels, breaking her way
 Pushing through unknown jungles every day
 She’s a girl with a taste for the world
 (The world is like a playing-ground where she goes rushing)
 Head over heels, setting the pace
 Running the gauntlet in a whirl of lace
 She’s extreme, if you know what I mean', [['According to Agnetha and Anni-Frid, she’s also a fearless woman. Life is like a game to her, and she is never afraid to play it rough. In a world in which many people are weak-minded, she is perfectly ready to be a strong-willed person.']])]

title: When All Is Said And Done
lyrics:
When All Is Said and Done Lyrics[Verse 1]
Here's to us, one more toast, and then we'll pay the bill
Deep inside, both of us can feel the autumn chill
Birds of passage, you and me
We fly instinctively
When the summer's over and the dark clouds hide the sun
Neither you nor I'm to blame when all is said and done

[Verse 2]
In our lives, we have walked some strange and lonely treks
Slightly worn, but dignified, and not too old for sex
We're still striving for the sky
No taste for humble pie
Thanks for all your generous love and thanks for all the fun
Neither you nor I'm to blame when all is said and done
[Interlude]

[Verse 3]
It's so strange, when you're down, and lying on the floor
How you rise, shake your head, get up and ask for more
Clear-headed and open-eyed
With nothing left untried
Standing calmly at the crossroads, no desire to run
There's no hurry anymore when all is said and done

[Outro]
Standing calmly at the crossroads, no desire to run
There's no hurry anymore when all is said and doneYou might also likeEmbed

title: Like An Angel Passing Through My Room
lyrics:
Like an Angel Passing Through My Room Lyrics[Verse 1]
Long awaited darkness falls
Casting shadows on the walls
In the twilight hour I am alone
Sitting near the fireplace, dying embers warm my face
In this peaceful solitude
All the outside world subdued
Everything comes back to me again
In the gloom
Like an angel passing through my room
[Verse 2]
Half awake and half in dreams
Seeing long forgotten scenes
So the present runs into the past
Now and then become entwined, playing games within my mind
Like the embers as they die
Love was one prolonged goodbye
And it all comes back to me tonight
In the gloom
Like an angel passing through my room

[Outro]
I close my eyes
And my twilight images go by
All too soon
Like an angel passing through my roomYou might also like1Embed

title: The Day Before You Came
lyrics:
The Day Before You Came Lyrics[Verse 1: Agnetha]
I must have left my house at eight because I always do
My train, I'm certain, left the station just when it was due
I must have read the morning paper going into town
And having gotten through the editorial no doubt I must have frowned
I must have made my desk around a quarter after nine
With letters to be read and heaps of papers waiting to be signed
I must have gone to lunch
At half past twelve or so, the usual place, the usual bunch
And still on top of this I'm pretty sure it must have rained
The day before you came
[Verse 2: Agnetha]
I must have lit my seventh cigarette at half past two
And at the time I never even noticed I was blue
I must have kept on dragging through the business of the day
Without really knowing anything I hid a part of me away
At five I must have left, there's no exception to the rule
A matter of routine, I've done it ever since I finished school
The train back home again
Undoubtedly I must have read the evening paper then
Oh yes, I'm sure my life was well within its usual frame
The day before you came

[Vocalisations: Frida]

[Verse 3: Agnetha]
I must have opened my front door at eight o'clock or so
And stopped along the way to buy some Chinese food to go
I'm sure I had my dinner watching something on TV
There's not, I think, a single episode of "Dallas" that I didn't see
I must have gone to bed around a quarter after ten
I need a lot of sleep and so I like to be in bed by then
I must have read a while
The latest one by Marilyn French, or something in that style
It's funny, but I had no sense of living without aim
The day before you came
You might also like[Outro: Agnetha]
And turning out the light
I must have yawned and cuddled up for yet another night
And rattling on the roof I must have heard the sound of rain
The day before you came

[Vocalisations: Frida]3Embed

title: Cassandra
lyrics:
Cassandra Lyrics[Verse 1]
Down in the street they're all singing and shouting
Staying alive though the city is dead
Hiding their shame behind hollow laughter
While you are crying alone in your bed
Pity, Cassandra, that no one believed you
But, then again, you were lost from the start
Now we must suffer and sell our secrets
Bargain, playing smart, aching in our hearts

[Chorus]
Sorry Cassandra, I misunderstood
Now the last day is dawning
Some of us wanted but none of us would
Listen to words of warning
But on the darkest of nights
Nobody knew how to fight
And we were caught in our sleep
Sorry Cassandra, I didn't believe
You really had the power
I only saw it as dreams you would weave
Until the final hour
[Verse 2]
So in the morning your ship will be sailing
Now that your father and sister are gone
There is no reason for you to linger
You're grieving deeply ,still moving on
You know the future is casting a shadow
No one else sees it, but you know your fate
Packing your bags, being slow and thorough
Knowing, though you're late, that ship is sure to wait

[Chorus]
Sorry Cassandra, I misunderstood
Now the last day is dawning
Some of us wanted but none of us would
Listen to words of warning
But on the darkest of nights
Nobody knew how to fight
And we were caught in our sleep
Sorry Cassandra, I didn't believe
You really had the power
I only saw it as dreams you would weave
Until the final hour

[Verse 3]
I watched the ship leaving harbour at sunrise
Sails almost slack in the cool morning rain
She stood on deck, just a tiny figure
Rigid and restrained, blue eyes filled with pain
You might also like[Chorus]
Sorry Cassandra, I misunderstood
Now the last day is dawning
Some of us wanted but none of us would
Listen to words of warning
But on the darkest of nights
Nobody knew how to fight
And we were caught in our sleep
Sorry Cassandra, I didn't believe
You really had the power
I only saw it as dreams you would weave
Until the final hour

[Outro]
(I'm sorry Cassandra)
(I'm sorry Cassandra)
(I'm sorry Cassandra)
(I'm sorry Cassandra)
(I'm sorry Cassandra)1Embed
annotation: [('Pity, Cassandra, that no one believed you', [['Cassandra, in Greek mythology, was beloved of Apollo, and because he loved her he gave her the gift of prophecy. However, she did not return his love. As he could not take back the gift, he angrily cursed her that no one would believe her prophecies. Cassandra repeatedly warned her fellow Trojans about the Greek warriors hiding inside the Trojan Horse, but no one believed her.']])]

Put on your white sombrero

You'd better go for there is no
Place for you here

[Verse 2]
Like an old fashioned hero
You stand before me
Oh, you think our life is a movie
My world is real I live and feel

Put on your white sombrero

Put on your white sombrero

Somebody meek, who'll never speak

You're such a caballero
Proud, never bending

Who is in rhyme with his time

title: En sång och en saga
lyrics:
En Sång Och En Saga Lyrics[Verse 1: Agnetha Fältskog]
Vad världen förändras, vad tiden går fort
Så mycket du drömde, som aldrig blev gjort
En sommar blir vinter, de varvar varann
Du drunknar i minnen från år som försvann
Din barndom förbleknar i minnenas ljus
Du minns episoder. en gata, ett hus!

[Chorus: Agnetha Fältskog]
En sång och en saga är hela vårt liv
En sång och en saga, ett kort tidsfördriv
En sång och en saga som handlar om mig
En sång och en saga, men även om dig!
[Verse 2: Agnetha Fältskog]
Vi drömmer om våren och när den är här
Så visar sig våren blott va' en chimar
Så kort är vår ungdom, en sommar, en dans
Snabbt jagar oss åren och bleker dess glans!

[Chorus: Agnetha Fältskog]
En sång och en saga är hela vårt liv
En sång och en saga, ett kort tidsfördriv
En sång och en saga som handlar om mig
En sång och en saga som handlar om mig
En sång och en saga, men även om dig!

[Chorus: Agnetha Fältskog, (Orchestra)]
(En sång och en saga är hela vårt liv)
(En sång och en saga, ett kort tidsfördriv)
En sång och en saga som handlar om mig
En sång och en saga, men även om dig!You might also likeEmbed
annotation:
[('Vi drömmer om våren och när den är här
 Så visar sig våren blott va’ en chimar
 Så kort är vår ungdom, en sommar, en dans
 Snabbt jagar oss åren och bleker dess glans!', [['Translation from Swedish:
We dream of spring and when it is here,
Spring turns out to be just an illusion.
Our youth is so short, a summer, a dance
The years quickly chase us and the light fades!']]), ('En sång och en saga är hela vårt liv
 En sång och en saga, ett kort tidsfördriv
 En sång och en saga som handlar om mig
 En sång och en saga, men även om dig!', [['Translation from Swedish:
A song and a story is what our lives are
A song and a story, a short pastime
A song and a story which is all about me
A song and a story – but also about you!']]), ('Vad världen förändras, vad tiden går fort
 Så mycket du drömde, som aldrig blev gjort
 En sommar blir vinter, de varvar varann
 Du drunknar i minnen från år som försvann
 Din barndom förbleknar i minnenas ljus
 Du minns episoder. en gata, ett hus!', [['Translation from Swedish:
How the world is changing, how fast the time goes by
You dreamt of doing so many things that never got done
A summer turns to winter, they keep taking turns
You drown in the memories of years that have disappeared
Your childhood is bathed in the light of memories
You remember episodes – a street, a house!']])]

title: S.O.S.

Var är den lycka som Jag en gång drömde om?
Du har förländrat dig och är sa långt frn mig

annotation:

 Var är han, denne man, som jag älskade så', [['Translation from Swedish:
Why should you and I go like two strangers?
Where is he, this man, whom I loved so much?']]), ('Den stora kärleken, vart tog den vägen san

The great love, where did that path go true

Say who can answer and who can explain? S.O.S

Who are you, as I now, do not recognize
Where is he, this man, who was once my friend?']]), ('Var är den lycka som Jag en gång drömde om?

title: En sång om sorg och glädje
lyrics:
En Sång Om Sorg Och Glädje Lyrics[Verse 1: Agnetha Fältskog]
Dagen må va' dyster, morgonen va' kall
Om jag riktigt lyssnar, hörs en sång i alla fall
Genom allt det tunga, genom allt det grå
Lyckas dessa toner att nå fram till mig ändå

[Chorus: Agnetha Fältskog & Orchestra]
Genom vardagen går en melodi
Gjord av två i förtrolighet och sympati
Från den första våren, har den genom åren
Troget följt oss tröstat och stått bi
När jag vill, kan jag höra melodin
En sång om sorg och glädje ljuder spröd och fin
Om än vardan är grå, så hörs sången ändå
Det känns som om den fångar all min sorg och glädje
[Verse 2: Agnetha Fältskog]
Sången speglar drömmar, dem vi haft en gång

annotation:
[('Sången speglar drömmar, dem vi haft en gång
 Olust och bekymmer finns där också i vår sång
 Där finns illusioner, glädje och finess
 Allt som speglar livet, även vemod och tristess', [['Translated from Swedish:
The song reflects the dreams, the ones we once had,
Dissatisfaction and worries are also in our song,
There are illusions, happiness and finesse
Everything reflecting life itself, even sadness and sorrow.']]), ('Genom vardagen går en melodi
 Gjord av två i förtrolighet och sympati
 Från den första våren, har den genom åren
 Troget följt oss tröstat och stått bi
 När jag vill, kan jag höra melodin
 En sång om sorg och glädje ljuder spröd och fin
 Om än vardan är grå, så hörs sången ändå
 Det känns som om den fångar all min sorg och glädje', [['Translated from Swedish:
Through the day flows a melody
Made by two in familiarity and sympathy,
From that first spring, it has through the years
Followed us faithfully, comforted and stood by us.
When I want, I can hear the melody
A song of sorrow and joy sounds so fragile and fine
Even if the day is still gray, the song can still be heard
It feels as if it captures all my sorrow and joy.']]), ('Dagen må va’ dyster, morgonen va’ kall
 Om jag riktigt lyssnar, hörs en sång i alla fall
 Genom allt det tunga, genom allt det grå
 Lyckas dessa toner att nå fram till mig ändå', [['Translated from Swedish:
The day may be dreary, the morning may be cold,
If I truly listen, I can still hear a song,
Through all the hard times, through all the gloom,
These notes manage to still reach me.']])]

annotation:
[('And how could I ever refuse?
 I feel like I win when I lose', [['Unlike Napoleon Bonaparte, who certainly did not feel as though he won after losing the Battle of Waterloo (he was exiled to St. Helena, where he died in 1821), this singer doesn’t mind “losing” because the result is that she is now with her lover.']]), ('My, my - I tried to hold you back, but you were stronger
 Oh, yeah - and now it seems my only chance is giving up the fight', [["At the Battle of Waterloo, the French (led by Napoleon) only had an army of 72,000 while the Anglo-led Allied European coalition had nearly 120,000 soldiers.

That said, despite the Allies' numerical advantage, Napoleon nearly won at Waterloo. The Duke of Wellington called the battle “the nearest run thing you ever saw in your life.”

Napoleon was also accustomed to victory in spite of numerical disadvantage – his most auspicious victory was the Battle of Austerlitz, where he decisively and simultaneously defeated   the Holy Roman Empire and Russia, despite his 67,000 soldiers being outnumbered by their 85,400."]]), ('My, my - at Waterloo, Napoleon did surrender
 Oh, yeah - and I have met my destiny in quite a similar way', [['Napoleon Bonaparte was decisively defeated by an Anglo-led European coalition at the Battle of Waterloo in 1815. This song uses the battle as a metaphor for a woman who gives in and falls in love with a man – he’s her “Waterloo.”

This line is actually historically inaccurate, however. Waterloo did mark Napoleon’s final defeat, but he did not surrender at the battle itself on June 18. He instead retreated to France, abdicating on June 24, and surrendering on July 15.']])]

annotation:
[('[Intro]', [['A whimsical orchestral musical lead through – to a fictitious tale of a historical battle survivors.

This song is Pop at his best, and it was a fresh change from the rule of disco in the latter part of the 70’s.']]), ('Now we’re old and grey, Fernando', [['The song writer, Bjotn Ulvaeus, had said in an interview –

That lyric [of the original song in Swedish] is so banal and I didn’t like it. It was a love lyric, someone who loved Fernando, but I inherited the word ‘Fernando’ and I thought long and hard, what does Fernando tell me? I was in my summerhouse one starry evening and the words came, ‘There was something in the air that night’ and I thought of two old comrades from some guerrilla war in Mexico who would be sitting in the porch and reminiscing about what happened to them back then and this is what it is all about. Total fiction.

From here']]), ('There was something in the air that night
 The stars were bright, Fernando', [['These corny lines were inviting a parody – they were used in an episode of That 70’s Show TV sitcom, incorporated into the spoken (an sung) narrative.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w0r3oYB2rV8']]), ('Yes, if I had to do the same again
 I would, my friend, Fernando', [['Despite being Abba’s most successful song, it was played only for a few seconds in the musical Mamma Mia which was built around the group’s songs – both in the stage production and in the film, hummed by Donna for a few seconds, while repairing a door in the taverna.



Fortunately, un “Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again”, however, the song does appear, as Ruby Sheridan meets her long-ago friend and lover, Fernando Cienfuegos.']]), ('[Verse 3]', [['Again – melodious, far from rock, though the Bass chords lines have been praised by many.']]), ('I could hear the distant drums and sounds of bugle calls were coming from afar', [['Another clue to their role in the war – sounds “were coming from afar” – and why they survived to tell the (fictitious) story…



Drums and bugle players indeed accompanied troops in the 19th century.']]), ('I remember, long ago, another starry night like this
 In the firelight, Fernando', [['Not to be too picky – these are nice rhymes, but it is doubtful they saw too many stars “in the firelight”, even if it was a “starry night”.

Or perhaps it was a subconscious referral for much more likely situation of “seeing stars” in a fight –']]), ('Do you still recall the fateful night we crossed the Rio Grande?', [['The Rio Grande – “The Grand River” that flows from the Rockies through New Mexico into Mexico and to the gulf of Mexico, serving since 1848 as the border between Mexico and the United States.



It serves as the scene for the fictitious story in the song of two soldiers, probably Mexicans, participating in the Mexican American War of 1846-8, revolving around the Rio Grands.

Another possibility is that it was a (fictitious again) song by veterans of the Mexican Revolution of 1910.']]), ('There was something in the air that night
 The stars were bright, Fernando', [['The song was originally recorded solo by Abba singer Anni-Frid Lyngstad as a love song with same name. The lyricist (the male members of Abba) decided that the Swedish lyrics were too corny, so they rewrote the lyrics in  English to sound less inane..

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_QKLMCssXzs

The song’s original name was Tango, then Hernandez and finally some combination of the two…

The chorus translation –

“Long live love, our best friend, Fernando.
Raise your glass and propose a toast to it, to love, Fernando.
Play the melody and sing a song of happiness.
Long live love, Fernando.

These two lines are probably the only ones that survived from the original version.']])]

annotation:
[('[Verse 2]', [['Similar to “I Do, I Do, I Do, I Do, I Do” from their previous album, “Dancing Queen” originally had more lyrics during the demoing process. The following lines can be heard in a recording session and would have ultimately made the second verse equal in length to the first:

Baby, baby, you’re out of sight
Hey, you’re looking alright tonight
When you come to the party, listen to the guys
They’ve got the look in their eyes

While these lines don’t appear in the English recording, the Spanish rerecording includes this lengthening of the verse, though the words are not a translation of the above.']]), ('Night is young and the music’s high', [['Many fans misinterpret this lyric, thinking it’s about music making you high—but in ABBA’s native Sweden, “high” means “loud.”']])]

title: Money, Money, Money

annotation:
[('There never seems to be a single penny left for me', [['This line is possibly autobiographical and an allegorical reference to what was happening in the group’s own country.

When Sweden was facing a 1976 general election, there was a debate around taxation and scrutinisation of the Social Democratic Party and its leader Olof Palme. The actions of the Swedish government, regarding taxation, has affected celebrities ranging from author Astrid Lindgren to director Ingmar Bergman.

Lindgren famously proclaimed that her taxation rate was 102% percent in her story “Pomperipossa in Monismania”, published in March 1976; interestingly, in the story, when Pomperipossa calculates what will be left to her, the calculation gave her 2,000 kronor, which infuriated her to the point that she questioned how she would get her food, while the rest of the kronor went to the welfare state, as Expressen elaborates in 2007. “A single penny” is not a single penny in a literal sense, but a metaphor of saying that there is remaining money for a person, but not enough to sustain themselves.

Bergman was reportedly charged for evading taxes through a foreign company based in Switzerland that distributed films outside Sweden. While he did indeed form a distribution company, he denied that he had any intentions to bypass Sweden’s tax system, according to the New York Times. Altogether, the taxation conflicts and grievances soon became a catalyst for ousting the Social Democratic Party from being the majority party in the Riksdag in the 1976 election.

Although this single and its accompanying album Arrival was released after the election and Lindgren’s story, The Guardian, Petter Karlsson and Jan Gradvall, in their 2014 book “ABBA: The Official Photo Book” revealed that ABBA and Polar Music avoided heavy taxation by wearing glam-inspired clothes that were to be used for only performances and not for the streets. In short, ABBA, to a certain extent, were not very fond of taxation.']]), ('So I must leave, I’ll have to go
 To Las Vegas or Monaco
 And win a fortune in a game
 My life will never be the same', [['If her rich husband is nowhere in sight, she muses that the easiest way to get the money would be through gambling. The fact that she must resort to random chance serves to further emphasize how unlikely it is that she would become rich.

Las Vegas and Monaco are the two most recognizable gambling destinations. Las Vegas is home to world famous casinos, and is almost synonymous with gambling, while Monaco is a small European country, home to the Monte Carlo Casino.']]), ('If I got me a wealthy man
 I wouldn’t have to work at all
 I’d fool around and have a ball', [['If she had a wealthy husband, she’d never have to work another day in her life. Gold Digger anyone?

This plays on the double meaning of “a ball.” In this life she would “have a ball,” or have fun not working, but she might also decide to host a formal party- the sort of masquerade ball so often associated with fairy tales.']])]

annotation:
[('We can go dancing, we can go walking
 As long as we’re together (As long as we’re together)
 Listen to some music, maybe just talking
 Get to know you better (Get to know you better)', [['They’re picturing all the romantic things they could do together if they were a couple. However, they may have romanticized the idea of this person a bit much. Sometimes when you have an idea of someone, they don’t live up to what you painted it to be in your mind.']]), ('If you need me, let me know, gonna be around', [['They will always be there for this person. It seems like a bit of a one way street – with a lot of care being given and none being reciprocated but the singer doesn’t mind.

The “pretty birds” may refer to all the other pretty girls/guys the person has in their life. When they’ve all left, he/she will still be there waiting. Birds also migrate to different countries during winter, and in this context they could be referring to the cold and hard times of life. Even in the cold and difficult times, they’ll still be there to support.']])]

annotation:
[('Voulez-vous?', [['This could very well be a reference to the cabaret song Lady Marmalade, by Patti Labelle, which topped the charts in 1974 and 1975, a few years before this hit was released:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zgLSeBPfVNM

It popularized the French expression:

Voulez-vous coucher avec moi ce soir ?"

Which literaly means: “Do you wanna sleep with me tonight?”']]), ('La question c’est «Voulez-vous?»
 Voulez-vous?', [['This line translates to “The question is ‘do you want to’” in English. Again, a furthering of the song’s theme of push and pull between two people who meet at a bar and are uncertain of the next step. Except in gratituous French.']])]

title: The Winner Takes It All
lyrics:
The Winner Takes It All Lyrics[Verse 1]
I don't wanna talk
About things we've gone through
Though it's hurting me, now it's history
I've played all my cards
And that's what you've done, too
Nothing more to say, no more ace to play

[Chorus]
The winner takes it all
The loser's standing small
Beside the victory
That's her destiny
[Verse 2]
I was in your arms
Thinking I belonged there
I figured it made sense, building me a fence
Building me a home
Thinking I'd be strong there
But I was a fool playing by the rules

[Chorus]

Their minds as cold as ice
And someone way down here
Loses someone dear
The winner takes it all (Takes it all)
The loser has to fall (Has to fall)
It's simple and it's plain (It seems plain)
Why should I complain? (Why complain)

[Verse 3]
But tell me, does she kiss
Like I used to kiss you?

But what can I say? Rules must be obeyed

The likes of me abide (We abide)

Always staying low (Staying low)
The game is on again (On again)
A lover or a friend (Or a friend)
A big thing or a small (Big or small)
The winner takes it all (Takes it all)

[Verse 4]
I don't wanna talk
If it makes you feel sad
And I understand, you've come to shake my hand
I apologise
If it makes you feel bad
Seeing me so tense, no self-confidence

[Bridge]
But you see, the winner takes it all
The winner takes it all

[Outro]
(So the winner)
(Takes it all)
(And the loser)
(Has to fall)
(Throw a dice)
(Cold as ice)
(Way down here)
(Someone dear)
(Takes it all)
(Has to fall)
(It seems plain)
(Why complain)18Embed
annotation:
[('The gods may throw a dice
 Their minds as cold as ice
 And someone way down here
 Loses someone dear', [['Think this lyrics may be related to teological determinism; the consideration of the idea that divine higher beings have the power to dictate the events in earth, on this case it being related to a breakup.']]), ('Spectators of the show (Of the show)
 Always staying low (Staying low)', [['These two lines depict a messy public fight, not unlike their divorce that received heavy media coverage. The journalists watching the fight stay out of sight, snapping photographs to be printed the next day. It’s also likely that Ulvaeus and Fältskog are taking a dig at journalists that write false stories.

In a 1981 interview with The Daily Mirror,Agnetha said:

Swedish newspapers always write untruths about me, so I know that no one is going to believe me, but I really don’t have a steady boyfriend

By calling them spectators, they opine that journalists are complete outsiders and don’t really matter too much to them.']]), ('The game is on again (On again)
 A lover or a friend (Or a friend)
 A big thing or a small (Big or small)
 The winner takes it all (Takes it all)', [['Ulvaeus and Fältskog are locked in a heated battle regarding their divorce and the custody of their children.

Björn Ulvaeus has argued that the song isn’t about his and Fältskog’s divorce but instead a piece of fiction:

There was not one winner in the case of us, so it’s pure fiction. But going through a divorce is difficult as anyone would know who has done it and er, it makes you think about it’s like a failure, yeah, it’s difficult and er, maybe that was one way of getting it out of my system.

But in a 2013 interview with The Daily Mail, Agnetha Fältskog described the song very differently.

Björn wrote it about us after the breakdown of our marriage. The fact he wrote it exactly when we divorced is touching really. I didn’t mind. It was fantastic to do that song because I could put in such feeling.']]), ('The judges will decide (They decide)
 The likes of me abide (We abide)', [['Frontman for ABBA at the time Björn Ulvaeus and his wife and fellow recording artist Agnetha Fältskog had two children when they divorced.

As this song was written by Ulvaeus, these lyrics are likely him lamenting that Fältskog got custody of their children and not him.']])]

annotation: [('Super Trouper beams are gonna blind me', [['Super Trouper lights are spotlights that are designed to shine bright on stages. In 1956, when such lights were introduced to the public, they were considered to be the brightest lights in the world, hence why the singers seem to be “blinded” by the lights.\n\nAfter the release of the song, the Super Troupers became one of the best known stage lights in the stage industry.']])]

title: The Day Before You Came
lyrics:
The Day Before You Came Lyrics[Verse 1: Agnetha]
I must have left my house at eight because I always do
My train, I'm certain, left the station just when it was due
I must have read the morning paper going into town
And having gotten through the editorial no doubt I must have frowned
I must have made my desk around a quarter after nine
With letters to be read and heaps of papers waiting to be signed
I must have gone to lunch
At half past twelve or so, the usual place, the usual bunch
And still on top of this I'm pretty sure it must have rained
The day before you came
[Verse 2: Agnetha]
I must have lit my seventh cigarette at half past two
And at the time I never even noticed I was blue
I must have kept on dragging through the business of the day
Without really knowing anything I hid a part of me away
At five I must have left, there's no exception to the rule
A matter of routine, I've done it ever since I finished school
The train back home again
Undoubtedly I must have read the evening paper then
Oh yes, I'm sure my life was well within its usual frame
The day before you came

[Vocalisations: Frida]

[Verse 3: Agnetha]
I must have opened my front door at eight o'clock or so
And stopped along the way to buy some Chinese food to go
I'm sure I had my dinner watching something on TV
There's not, I think, a single episode of "Dallas" that I didn't see
I must have gone to bed around a quarter after ten
I need a lot of sleep and so I like to be in bed by then
I must have read a while
The latest one by Marilyn French, or something in that style
It's funny, but I had no sense of living without aim
The day before you came
You might also like[Outro: Agnetha]
And turning out the light
I must have yawned and cuddled up for yet another night
And rattling on the roof I must have heard the sound of rain
The day before you came

[Vocalisations: Frida]3Embed

annotation:
[('And how could I ever refuse?
 I feel like I win when I lose', [['Unlike Napoleon Bonaparte, who certainly did not feel as though he won after losing the Battle of Waterloo (he was exiled to St. Helena, where he died in 1821), this singer doesn’t mind “losing” because the result is that she is now with her lover.']]), ('My, my - I tried to hold you back, but you were stronger
 Oh, yeah - and now it seems my only chance is giving up the fight', [["At the Battle of Waterloo, the French (led by Napoleon) only had an army of 72,000 while the Anglo-led Allied European coalition had nearly 120,000 soldiers.

That said, despite the Allies' numerical advantage, Napoleon nearly won at Waterloo. The Duke of Wellington called the battle “the nearest run thing you ever saw in your life.”

Napoleon was also accustomed to victory in spite of numerical disadvantage – his most auspicious victory was the Battle of Austerlitz, where he decisively and simultaneously defeated   the Holy Roman Empire and Russia, despite his 67,000 soldiers being outnumbered by their 85,400."]]), ('My, my - at Waterloo, Napoleon did surrender
 Oh, yeah - and I have met my destiny in quite a similar way', [['Napoleon Bonaparte was decisively defeated by an Anglo-led European coalition at the Battle of Waterloo in 1815. This song uses the battle as a metaphor for a woman who gives in and falls in love with a man – he’s her “Waterloo.”

This line is actually historically inaccurate, however. Waterloo did mark Napoleon’s final defeat, but he did not surrender at the battle itself on June 18. He instead retreated to France, abdicating on June 24, and surrendering on July 15.']])]

annotation:
[('[Intro]', [['A whimsical orchestral musical lead through – to a fictitious tale of a historical battle survivors.

This song is Pop at his best, and it was a fresh change from the rule of disco in the latter part of the 70’s.']]), ('Now we’re old and grey, Fernando', [['The song writer, Bjotn Ulvaeus, had said in an interview –

That lyric [of the original song in Swedish] is so banal and I didn’t like it. It was a love lyric, someone who loved Fernando, but I inherited the word ‘Fernando’ and I thought long and hard, what does Fernando tell me? I was in my summerhouse one starry evening and the words came, ‘There was something in the air that night’ and I thought of two old comrades from some guerrilla war in Mexico who would be sitting in the porch and reminiscing about what happened to them back then and this is what it is all about. Total fiction.

From here']]), ('There was something in the air that night
 The stars were bright, Fernando', [['These corny lines were inviting a parody – they were used in an episode of That 70’s Show TV sitcom, incorporated into the spoken (an sung) narrative.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w0r3oYB2rV8']]), ('Yes, if I had to do the same again
 I would, my friend, Fernando', [['Despite being Abba’s most successful song, it was played only for a few seconds in the musical Mamma Mia which was built around the group’s songs – both in the stage production and in the film, hummed by Donna for a few seconds, while repairing a door in the taverna.



Fortunately, un “Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again”, however, the song does appear, as Ruby Sheridan meets her long-ago friend and lover, Fernando Cienfuegos.']]), ('[Verse 3]', [['Again – melodious, far from rock, though the Bass chords lines have been praised by many.']]), ('I could hear the distant drums and sounds of bugle calls were coming from afar', [['Another clue to their role in the war – sounds “were coming from afar” – and why they survived to tell the (fictitious) story…



Drums and bugle players indeed accompanied troops in the 19th century.']]), ('I remember, long ago, another starry night like this
 In the firelight, Fernando', [['Not to be too picky – these are nice rhymes, but it is doubtful they saw too many stars “in the firelight”, even if it was a “starry night”.

Or perhaps it was a subconscious referral for much more likely situation of “seeing stars” in a fight –']]), ('Do you still recall the fateful night we crossed the Rio Grande?', [['The Rio Grande – “The Grand River” that flows from the Rockies through New Mexico into Mexico and to the gulf of Mexico, serving since 1848 as the border between Mexico and the United States.



It serves as the scene for the fictitious story in the song of two soldiers, probably Mexicans, participating in the Mexican American War of 1846-8, revolving around the Rio Grands.

Another possibility is that it was a (fictitious again) song by veterans of the Mexican Revolution of 1910.']]), ('There was something in the air that night
 The stars were bright, Fernando', [['The song was originally recorded solo by Abba singer Anni-Frid Lyngstad as a love song with same name. The lyricist (the male members of Abba) decided that the Swedish lyrics were too corny, so they rewrote the lyrics in  English to sound less inane..

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_QKLMCssXzs

The song’s original name was Tango, then Hernandez and finally some combination of the two…

The chorus translation –

“Long live love, our best friend, Fernando.
Raise your glass and propose a toast to it, to love, Fernando.
Play the melody and sing a song of happiness.
Long live love, Fernando.

These two lines are probably the only ones that survived from the original version.']])]

title: Money, Money, Money
lyrics:
Money, Money, Money Lyrics[Verse 1]
I work all night, I work all day, to pay the bills I have to pay
Ain't it sad?
And still, there never seems to be a single penny left for me
That's too bad

[Pre-Chorus]
In my dreams, I have a plan
If I got me a wealthy man
I wouldn't have to work at all
I'd fool around and have a ball
[Chorus]
Money, money, money
Must be funny
In the rich man's world
Money, money, money
Always sunny
In the rich man's world
A-ha, ah
All the things I could do
If I had a little money
It's a rich man's world

[Verse 2]
A man like that is hard to find, but I can't get him off my mind
Ain't it sad?
And if he happens to be free, I bet he wouldn't fancy me
That's too bad

[Pre-Chorus]
So I must leave, I'll have to go
To Las Vegas or Monaco
And win a fortune in a game
My life will never be the same

[Chorus]
Money, money, money
Must be funny
In the rich man's world
Money, money, money
Always sunny
In the rich man's world
A-ha, ah
All the things I could do
If I had a little money
It's a rich man's world
You might also like[Chorus]
Money, money, money
Must be funny
In the rich man's world
Money, money, money
Always sunny
In the rich man's world
A-ha, ah
All the things I could do
If I had a little money
It's a rich man's world

[Outro]
It's a rich man's world15Embed
annotation:
[('There never seems to be a single penny left for me', [['This line is possibly autobiographical and an allegorical reference to what was happening in the group’s own country.

When Sweden was facing a 1976 general election, there was a debate around taxation and scrutinisation of the Social Democratic Party and its leader Olof Palme. The actions of the Swedish government, regarding taxation, has affected celebrities ranging from author Astrid Lindgren to director Ingmar Bergman.

Lindgren famously proclaimed that her taxation rate was 102% percent in her story “Pomperipossa in Monismania”, published in March 1976; interestingly, in the story, when Pomperipossa calculates what will be left to her, the calculation gave her 2,000 kronor, which infuriated her to the point that she questioned how she would get her food, while the rest of the kronor went to the welfare state, as Expressen elaborates in 2007. “A single penny” is not a single penny in a literal sense, but a metaphor of saying that there is remaining money for a person, but not enough to sustain themselves.

Bergman was reportedly charged for evading taxes through a foreign company based in Switzerland that distributed films outside Sweden. While he did indeed form a distribution company, he denied that he had any intentions to bypass Sweden’s tax system, according to the New York Times. Altogether, the taxation conflicts and grievances soon became a catalyst for ousting the Social Democratic Party from being the majority party in the Riksdag in the 1976 election.

Although this single and its accompanying album Arrival was released after the election and Lindgren’s story, The Guardian, Petter Karlsson and Jan Gradvall, in their 2014 book “ABBA: The Official Photo Book” revealed that ABBA and Polar Music avoided heavy taxation by wearing glam-inspired clothes that were to be used for only performances and not for the streets. In short, ABBA, to a certain extent, were not very fond of taxation.']]), ('So I must leave, I’ll have to go
 To Las Vegas or Monaco
 And win a fortune in a game
 My life will never be the same', [['If her rich husband is nowhere in sight, she muses that the easiest way to get the money would be through gambling. The fact that she must resort to random chance serves to further emphasize how unlikely it is that she would become rich.

Las Vegas and Monaco are the two most recognizable gambling destinations. Las Vegas is home to world famous casinos, and is almost synonymous with gambling, while Monaco is a small European country, home to the Monte Carlo Casino.']]), ('If I got me a wealthy man
 I wouldn’t have to work at all
 I’d fool around and have a ball', [['If she had a wealthy husband, she’d never have to work another day in her life. Gold Digger anyone?

This plays on the double meaning of “a ball.” In this life she would “have a ball,” or have fun not working, but she might also decide to host a formal party- the sort of masquerade ball so often associated with fairy tales.']])]

annotation:
[('We can go dancing, we can go walking
 As long as we’re together (As long as we’re together)
 Listen to some music, maybe just talking
 Get to know you better (Get to know you better)', [['They’re picturing all the romantic things they could do together if they were a couple. However, they may have romanticized the idea of this person a bit much. Sometimes when you have an idea of someone, they don’t live up to what you painted it to be in your mind.']]), ('If you need me, let me know, gonna be around', [['They will always be there for this person. It seems like a bit of a one way street – with a lot of care being given and none being reciprocated but the singer doesn’t mind.

The “pretty birds” may refer to all the other pretty girls/guys the person has in their life. When they’ve all left, he/she will still be there waiting. Birds also migrate to different countries during winter, and in this context they could be referring to the cold and hard times of life. Even in the cold and difficult times, they’ll still be there to support.']])]

title: Voulez-Vous
lyrics:
Voulez-Vous Lyrics[Verse 1]

annotation:
[('Voulez-vous?', [['This could very well be a reference to the cabaret song Lady Marmalade, by Patti Labelle, which topped the charts in 1974 and 1975, a few years before this hit was released:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zgLSeBPfVNM

It popularized the French expression:

Voulez-vous coucher avec moi ce soir ?"

Which literaly means: “Do you wanna sleep with me tonight?”']]), ('La question c’est «Voulez-vous?»
 Voulez-vous?', [['This line translates to “The question is ‘do you want to’” in English. Again, a furthering of the song’s theme of push and pull between two people who meet at a bar and are uncertain of the next step. Except in gratituous French.']])]

title: Angeleyes

I keep thinking

And I thought maybe I should walk right up to her and say
"Ah-ha-ha, it's a game he likes to play"
